Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Exploring Theoretical Foundation of Mobile Cloud: From One-Hop Neighbors to the Internet

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The number of smartphones in use worldwide reached 1.038 billion units during the third quarter of 2012, and smartphone users are expected to be over 2 billion by 2015. With this fast-growing and a large asset of tablets and smartphones, the sheer number and density of wireless devices has overwhelmed network resources to support the level of quality expected by users. Utilizing cloud computing, mobile cloud computing (MCC) has been recently introduced to facilitate mobile users to take full advantages of cloud computing, even with the reduced available network capacity. The objective of this project is to explore fundamental issues that advance our understanding of using mobile clouds in delivering wireless data traffic.

The proposed work aims to (i) explore sufficient and necessary conditions of mobile cloudlets through one-hop communications to ensure short delay and easy management of task dispatch; (ii) identify theoretical limits of mobile cloudlets by harnessing the latest understanding of link-level dynamics with the focus on the discrepancy in homogeneous and heterogeneous mobile nodes in the evolution of mobile cloudlets over time; (iii) investigate new algorithms that detect mobile clouds that are based on not only their spatial locations, but other factors, such as power-saving, tethering access points, non-exponential inter-contact time distributions, as well as social connections among mobile devices; (iv) find how long and how far it could take before data arrives at the cloud in a hybrid network model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fast-growing and sheer volume of wireless and mobile devices has provided non-negligible resources for computing and communication. Along with the paradigm of cloud computing, mobile cloud computing (MCC) is introduced to facilitate mobile users to take full advantages of cloud computing. Applications ranging from mobile commerce to mobile learning with real-time interactive platform on mobile devices are based on a seemingly obvious question: can mobile cloud computing meet our expectation? How do we close the gap between the proliferating applications of mobile clouds and the lack of theoretical guidelines for the future success?

The objective of this project is to explore fundamental issues that advance our understanding of using mobile clouds in delivering wireless data traffic. This project aims to (i) explore sufficient and necessary conditions of mobile cloudlets through one-hop communications to ensure short delay and easy management of task dispatch; (ii) identify theoretical limits of mobile cloudlets by harnessing the latest understanding of wireless link-level dynamics with the focus on the discrepancy in homogeneous and heterogeneous mobile nodes in the evolution of mobile cloudlets over time; (iii) investigate new algorithms that detect mobile clouds that are based on not only their spatial locations, but other factors, such as power-saving, tethering access points, non-exponential inter-contact time distributions, as well as social connections among mobile devices; and (iv) find how long and how far it would take before data arrives at the cloud in a hybrid network model.

Specifically, we have obtained following outcomes:

1. In this project, we have conducted an in-depth analysis on how data and information spreads over multi-hop wireless/social networks and also devised a number of algorithms to efficiently get connected to other mobile users and access points, in a single hop considering user's mobility as well as over multihop via distributed and delay-efficient scheduling algorithms. For instance, we have developed WiFi sensing algorithms to reduce power-consumption and access delay by exploiting temporal dependency (memory structure) inherent in users' movement patterns, and a series of optimal CSMA scheduling algorithms that allow users to access the wireless link in a distributed manner, while preserving the same maximal long-term throughput but further reducing the delay compared to the existing algorithms. The latter is particularly relevant for multihop wireless networks in which many devices are to communicate with each other without any cell tower or access point. This was made possible by careful applications of the advanced Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling techniques onto wireless scheduling domain. In this context, we have also devised several ways to improve existing graph sampling algorithms via light-weight, distributed agents (random walks), under cost constraints and extended the horizon to directed graphs where the information/data flows from one node (user) to another, but possibly not the other way around.

2. We have also analyzed how the information/data/malware/virus spreads over possibly multihop wireless/social networks. We developed a time-varying SI epidemic model to explain the observed behavior, and derived much tighter bounds that can accurately predict how the epidemic spreads over time before it reaches its steady-state. These works have received the best paper award in NetSciCom 2015 and been recognized as one of the best paper award finalist in ACM MobiHoc 2019.

3. We have studied how to form a wireless cloudlet and how such a cloudlet can be used in practical applications. Specifically, we investigated whether a group of wireless devices can be associated as a cloudlet; and whether a wireless cloudlet is a better choice than infrastructure networks, such as cellular or access points. We formulated the problem for two applications: smart-grid as an example of cyber-physical systems and Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems. We considered that fault propagation in power systems being one of the most critical issues due to its catastrophic impact on electric power systems and potential casualty. Our approach is to implement both single-hop and multi-hop communications and examined the evolution process of information dissemination and fault propagation, and we also developed several new metrics, including the recovery time between two faults with and without using communication networks for two city-wide networks, that is IEEE 14-bus and FREEDM 18-bus systems with PCCAD and OMNet++. We found that communication latency must be within the latency limit for real systems to mitigate severe aftermath of faults or failures in real systems. Relevant works have been published in IEEE INFOCOM 2014 and IEEE Systems Journal 2019.

4. The project has also supported in training and graduating four PhD students, two of them being female, and developing a new graduate-level courses on Network Science at NC State University, focusing on wireless network (graph) formation, its dynamics, and randomized, efficient algorithms running on the graph and modeling approach for applications in vehicular networks.
